trans-unit.source: Manage virtual machine extensions | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage virtual machine extensions | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how to add, find, update, and remove extensions.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to add, find, update, and remove extensions.

trans-unit.source: Manage virtual machine extensions
trans-unit.target: Manage virtual machine extensions

trans-unit.source: Describes how to find, add, modify, or remove VM Extensions with either Windows or Linux Virtual Machines on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to find, add, modify, or remove VM Extensions with either Windows or Linux Virtual Machines on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Using VM Extensions
trans-unit.target: Using VM Extensions

trans-unit.source: Azure VM Extensions implement behaviors or features that either help other programs work on Azure VMs (for example, the **WebDeployForVSDevTest** extension allows Visual Studio to Web Deploy solutions on your Azure VM) or provide the ability for you to interact with the VM to support some other behavior (for example, you can use the VM Access extensions from Powershell, the Azure CLI, and REST clients to reset or modify remote access values on your Azure VM).
trans-unit.target: Azure VM Extensions implement behaviors or features that either help other programs work on Azure VMs (for example, the **WebDeployForVSDevTest** extension allows Visual Studio to Web Deploy solutions on your Azure VM) or provide the ability for you to interact with the VM to support some other behavior (for example, you can use the VM Access extensions from Powershell, the Azure CLI, and REST clients to reset or modify remote access values on your Azure VM).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] For a complete list of extensions by the features they support, see [Azure VM Extensions and Features](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn606311.aspx).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] For a complete list of extensions by the features they support, see [Azure VM Extensions and Features](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn606311.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Because each VM extension supports a specific feature, exactly what you can and cannot do with an extension depends on the extension.
trans-unit.target: Because each VM extension supports a specific feature, exactly what you can and cannot do with an extension depends on the extension.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, before modifying your VM, make sure you have read the documentation for the VM Extension you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, before modifying your VM, make sure you have read the documentation for the VM Extension you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Removing some VM Extensions is not supported; others have properties that can be set that change VM behavior radically.
trans-unit.target: Removing some VM Extensions is not supported; others have properties that can be set that change VM behavior radically.

trans-unit.source: The most common tasks are:
trans-unit.target: The most common tasks are:

trans-unit.source: Find Available Extensions
trans-unit.target: Find Available Extensions

trans-unit.source: Azure VM Extensions are (For a complete list of extensions by the features they support, see [Azure VM Extensions and Features](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn606311.aspx).) You can locate the extension and extended information using:
trans-unit.target: Azure VM Extensions are (For a complete list of extensions by the features they support, see [Azure VM Extensions and Features](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn606311.aspx).) You can locate the extension and extended information using:

trans-unit.source: PowerShell
trans-unit.target: PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Azure Cross-Platform Interface (Azure CLI)
trans-unit.target: Azure Cross-Platform Interface (Azure CLI)

trans-unit.source: Service Management REST API
trans-unit.target: Service Management REST API

trans-unit.source: either [Azure PowerShell](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495240.aspx) cmdlets or the [Service Management REST APIs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee460799.aspx) to find information about available extensions.
trans-unit.target: either [Azure PowerShell](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495240.aspx) cmdlets or the [Service Management REST APIs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee460799.aspx) to find information about available extensions.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Some extensions have Powershell cmdlets that are specific to them, which may make their configuration from PowerShell easier; but the following cmdlets work for all VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Some extensions have Powershell cmdlets that are specific to them, which may make their configuration from PowerShell easier; but the following cmdlets work for all VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following cmdlets to obtain information about available extensions:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following cmdlets to obtain information about available extensions:

trans-unit.source: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the [Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722498.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the [Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722498.aspx)

trans-unit.source: cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the [Get-AzureVMAvailableExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722480.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the [Get-AzureVMAvailableExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722480.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code example shows how to list the
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code example shows how to list the

trans-unit.source: information for the **IaaSDiagnostics** extension using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: information for the **IaaSDiagnostics** extension using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Azure Command Line Interface (Azure CLI)
trans-unit.target: Azure Command Line Interface (Azure CLI)

trans-unit.source: Some extensions have Azure CLI commands that are specific to them (the Docker VM Extension is one example), which may make their configuration easier; but the following commands work for all VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Some extensions have Azure CLI commands that are specific to them (the Docker VM Extension is one example), which may make their configuration easier; but the following commands work for all VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **azure vm extension list** command to obtain information about available extensions, and use the **–-json** option to display all available information about one or more extensions.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **azure vm extension list** command to obtain information about available extensions, and use the **–-json** option to display all available information about one or more extensions.

trans-unit.source: If you do not use an extension name, the command returns a json description of all available extensions.
trans-unit.target: If you do not use an extension name, the command returns a json description of all available extensions.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code example shows how to list the information for the **IaaSDiagnostics** extension using the Azure CLI **azure vm extension list** command and uses the **–-json** option to return complete information.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code example shows how to list the information for the **IaaSDiagnostics** extension using the Azure CLI **azure vm extension list** command and uses the **–-json** option to return complete information.

trans-unit.source: Service Management REST APIs
trans-unit.target: Service Management REST APIs

trans-unit.source: You can use the following REST APIs to obtain information about available extensions:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following REST APIs to obtain information about available extensions:

trans-unit.source: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the [List Available Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn169559.aspx) operation.
trans-unit.target: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the [List Available Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn169559.aspx) operation.

trans-unit.source: To list the versions of available extensions, you can use [List Extension Versions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495437.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To list the versions of available extensions, you can use [List Extension Versions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495437.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the [List Resource Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495441.aspx) operation.
trans-unit.target: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the [List Resource Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495441.aspx) operation.

trans-unit.source: To list the versions of available extensions, you can use [List Resource Extension Versions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495440.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To list the versions of available extensions, you can use [List Resource Extension Versions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495440.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Add, Update, or Disable Extensions
trans-unit.target: Add, Update, or Disable Extensions

trans-unit.source: Extensions can be added when an instance is created or they can be added to a running instance.
trans-unit.target: Extensions can be added when an instance is created or they can be added to a running instance.

trans-unit.source: Extensions can be updated, disabled, or removed.
trans-unit.target: Extensions can be updated, disabled, or removed.

trans-unit.source: You can perform these actions by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets or by using the Service Management REST API operations.
trans-unit.target: You can perform these actions by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets or by using the Service Management REST API operations.

trans-unit.source: Parameters are required to install and set up some extensions.
trans-unit.target: Parameters are required to install and set up some extensions.

trans-unit.source: Public and private parameters are supported for extensions.
trans-unit.target: Public and private parameters are supported for extensions.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell cmdlets is the easiest way to add and update extensions.
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell cmdlets is the easiest way to add and update extensions.

trans-unit.source: When you use the extension cmdlets, most of the configuration of the extension is done for you.
trans-unit.target: When you use the extension cmdlets, most of the configuration of the extension is done for you.

trans-unit.source: At times, you may need to programmatically add an extension.
trans-unit.target: At times, you may need to programmatically add an extension.

trans-unit.source: When you need to do this, you must provide the configuration of the extension.
trans-unit.target: When you need to do this, you must provide the configuration of the extension.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following cmdlets to know whether an extension requires a configuration of public and private parameters:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following cmdlets to know whether an extension requires a configuration of public and private parameters:

trans-unit.source: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the **Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: For instances of web roles or worker roles, you can use the **Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the **Get-AzureVMAvailableExtension** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: For instances of Virtual Machines, you can use the **Get-AzureVMAvailableExtension** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Service Management REST APIs
trans-unit.target: Service Management REST APIs

trans-unit.source: When you retrieve a listing of available extensions by using the REST
trans-unit.target: When you retrieve a listing of available extensions by using the REST

trans-unit.source: APIs, you receive information about how the extension is to be configured.
trans-unit.target: APIs, you receive information about how the extension is to be configured.

trans-unit.source: The information that is returned might show parameter information represented by a public schema and private schema.
trans-unit.target: The information that is returned might show parameter information represented by a public schema and private schema.

trans-unit.source: Public parameter values are returned in queries about the instances.
trans-unit.target: Public parameter values are returned in queries about the instances.

trans-unit.source: Private parameter values are not returned.
trans-unit.target: Private parameter values are not returned.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following REST APIs to know whether an extension requires a configuration of public and private parameters:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following REST APIs to know whether an extension requires a configuration of public and private parameters:

trans-unit.source: For instances of web roles or worker roles, the **PublicConfigurationSchema** and **PrivateConfigurationSchema** elements contain the information in the response from the [List Available Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn169559.aspx) operation.
trans-unit.target: For instances of web roles or worker roles, the **PublicConfigurationSchema** and **PrivateConfigurationSchema** elements contain the information in the response from the [List Available Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn169559.aspx) operation.

trans-unit.source: For instances of Virtual Machines, the **PublicConfigurationSchema** and **PrivateConfigurationSchema** elements contain the information in the response from the [List Resource Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495441.aspx) operation.
trans-unit.target: For instances of Virtual Machines, the **PublicConfigurationSchema** and **PrivateConfigurationSchema** elements contain the information in the response from the [List Resource Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495441.aspx) operation.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]Extensions can also use configurations that are defined with JSON.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]Extensions can also use configurations that are defined with JSON.

trans-unit.source: When these types of extensions are used, only the **SampleConfig** element is used.
trans-unit.target: When these types of extensions are used, only the **SampleConfig** element is used.
